post.descrizione: Villa Selvatico is spread over three floors articulated around the central halls in the shape of a Greek cross on the first and second floors. In the main vaulted hall, which can be accessed from the outside via the southern staircase built in Costozza stone, there are 6 small doors that give access to private rooms and two open-air loggias. Benedetto Selvatico, doctor and academic, commissioned the decorations in 1650 from two prominent figures in the circle of fresco artists active in the Padua area: Luca Ferrari, known as Luca da Reggio and Lorenzo Bedogni. The organizational aspect for the decoration of the central hall was taken care of by Bedogni, with the aim of leaving room for the narration of the events, guaranteeing a compositional rhythm that was not confusing for the observer. For his purpose, the painter used new decorative techniques imported from neighboring regions, such as the Emilian quadratura. However, the strong character of the Selvaticos is very evident. Benedetto personally drew up the iconographic program dedicated to the small decorative cycle of the foundation of Padua by the legendary Antenor. The academic had proposed to follow to the letter the descriptions of 1618 that the historian Cesare Ripa had dedicated to the series of allegorical figures.
